10.text:
Onto our closing keynote, we hope you
had a great day we hope that you noticed

18.text:
and you've been engaged in this thread

design and tech for good that has been

29.text:
very conscious to give you a closing

35.text:
themes and principles and ideas and so
without further ado let me hand over to

49.text: Hello everyone, my name is Molly

54.text:
I'm going to start with a brief overview of
myself and my condition

60.text:
I'm 21 years old,
at 18 months old I was registered severely

65.text:
deaf and I was getting my first pair of
analogue hearing aids. I can't really

70.text:
remember what that feels like at
18 months but I was given the gift of

79.text:
sound with these hearing aids
with a lot of work put in by my

84.text:
parents in speech therapists I was able to speak at
the age of six. By the time I got to the age

90.text:
of 12 I started struggling in the
classroom I couldn't see the board, I was

96.text:
struggling to lip read which for a deaf
person is quite a downfall. Because I was getting a lot

103.text:
of headache people thought maybe you need
reading glasses, so went along to the

108.text:
optician, and then  we
basically discovered this genetic condition

114.text:
called Usher Syndrome which is the most
common form of congenital deafblindness

122.text:
you're born deaf and then during
adolescence you start to lose your sight.

125.text:
So the blindness is called retinitis
pigmentosa and you start to lose your

131.text:
peripherals it kinda just closes up so,
I was told at 12

135.text:
I wouldn't see a massive difference in
my vision until I was in my mid to late 30s

140.text:
however when I got to the age of
fourteen I went from being partially

145.text:
sighted to severely impaired which is
politically correct for blind

149.text:
It was quite a quick journey shall we say but
if you've got any questions to do with my

157.text:
condition or my presentation I'll be
happy to take those at the end just

163.text:
going to go into a bit more about my
journey

165.text:
and why I'm here today.
Life has constantly been a battle for

170.text:
accessibility as you can imagine having
sensory loss it was all about how I

175.text:
could access that again, to begin with I
had these hearing aids which were great

179.text:
I kind of hated them to begin with because it
was quite overwhelming.

186.text:
Without my hearing aids I had nothing and
then with it was sound but

190.text:
all at once to the same level - a little
overwhelming

193.text:
Though I realized being in mainstream schools I
needed them in order to communicate

198.text: with my friends. Because of that, I've been

202.text:
fortunate, I went through
mainstream a happy child then when I

206.text:
got to year three, I remember this year
quite well, I was about eight and I went

212.text:
digital so I had my first pair of
digital hearing aids, and i have some

216.text:
really cool memories of when 
these first went in.

222.text:
With analogue it was more like black and white,
sound or nothing whereas the digital more tonal

228.text:
with more levels of hearing, I could
hear speech more clearly, I could hear

234.text:
echo, birdsong for the first time. I could
hear leaves crunching under my feet

241.text:
down at the park. It gave me much more
atmosphere to living

247.text:
through my sense of hearing which is
amazing I remember feeling so delighted

253.text:
at the fact I was experiencing more
outdoors as a deaf child. However as I

259.text:
mentioned with the syndrome
diagnosis things were not getting easier

264.text:
looking back now as a child I hated the
dark as well which was quite isolating

270.text:
which is actually one of the early
symptoms of retinitis pigmentosa -

275.text:
night blindness.
With my eyes getting progressively worse fairly quick

281.text:
I felt deafer if you like, because I wasn't able
to lip read people in a

285.text:
classroom my teachers although they had
radio waves, I had all these wires and bum

290.text:
bags and all the rest of it, it wasn't
enough, I wasn't having enough access my

296.text:
education. So I was provided with
this big clunky Dell computer which I

304.text:
absolutely despised it took me about 10
minutes to set up before a lesson and it

309.text:
came with additional software like an
old-fashioned projector, JAWS software

314.text:
meant to enlarge everything I
had on my screen.

318.text:
It was not inclusive, I felt very
different as a child I was alright being

323.text: the only one with hearing aids

325.text:
they were quite subtle whereas this kind
of really added to the label of being

330.text:
different. I did not get on with it
at all. It just so happened during this

337.text:
time, years 7-8, I had a friend who was very
into tech as her mum was working at Apple

345.text:
I would go around there and we would
often make movies using iMovie on their Mac

350.text:
computers - really quite fun! And through
these Macs I was made aware of

356.text:
the built-in accessability features on
the Mac system, this really changed

363.text:
the whole game for me - it was like 
"wow this is actually a cool thing!" I can

368.text:
actually access it and independently
adjust settings so I was quite fortunate that

374.text:
my parents were in a position where they
could provide a Macbook for me so I was

379.text:
given a Macbook and I was able to manually
adjuste exam papers, keynote,

383.text:
presentations, whatever that was on the
board in a classroom I could adjust to

388.text:
my own ability how, I wanted to have it,
which was amazing so from the age of 13

I went Apple, if you like, though my visual world
was progressively getting smaller

402.text:
my Apple collection grew - it went from having
just a MacBook and iPhone and iPad

407.text:
obviously iPhone and iPad have very
consistent accessability features as well.

412.text:
These tools were actually enabling me to do
things everyone else was doing with the

418.text:
use of the accessibility features
built-in. All the apps that come

423.text:
with that as well, downloading all the
apps really helped with my freedom,

427.text:
out and about too. 
So with the use of having an iPhone and

431.text:
an iPad - I used my iPad a lot in the
classroom as well, all of this got me through

438.text:
my GCSEs and even A levels. I managed to
get myself some pretty good grades.

442.text:
All of this was really building my
confidence because I was young child who

447.text:
was always quite different, but I was
strategizing to find a way through and I

really saw myself being a teacher. I liked
the idea of making a difference and

obviously starting with children's always
a good route. I've done a lot of work in

schools as well - I really enjoy working
with children. I worked really hard

through college to get the
points to get into university

473.text:
however some of you will probably know
that to get a teaching degree you have

479.text:

your A levels, so this was really

and this was my first obstacle really

500.text:
the government website were not accessible,
they had a thing for those who you have

507.text:
special needs and that was extra time
which is great however in order to get

512.text:
extra time you have to book over the
phone. Back then being deaf

518.text:
I couldn't access talking on the phone, it
wasn't doable. That was my first

523.text:
obstacle.Then once you're on the web
site on the test and being timed

527.text:
I couldn't even, with the
use of my tools, enlarge anything

533.text:
It was all completely inaccessible 
and a major barrier because

538.text:
I needed to do these skills tests to get into

I was really quite lucky because the college
were really supportive, so

in the end what happened was we had

college executed them. That's really

561.text:
So even though I studied
really really hard those tests were

565.text:
inaccessible, despite the
government based websites I had quite a

568.text:
confidence fall in the
beginning but I did make it and I was

573.text:
really proud of myself. I made it into
what was meant, I was told, to be in the

578.text:
top three for primary education in England however,
being there for a long five grueling

585.text:
months unfortunately, I sort of
feel like the system let me down a bit.

590.text:
A lot was promised, for example,
everything referred to the Moodle

595.text:
intranet, so I would be using my Mac,
but could I access it?

600.text:
No. The whole content refused to budge,
it would not enlarge at all

606.text:
whatever I used would not enlarge. 
Every single lecture referred the Moodle

611.text:
intranet, PowerPoint slides you name it,
then they promised print outs they'd modify for me.

619.text:
Never happened. I was going back and forth
to lecturers to try and remind them,

624.text:
of what been promised, a lot of the
time it was like

628.text:
"Oh, well if you're this blind then how
are you gonna cope in a classroom?"

634.text:
They were constantly doubting me as a person with
special needs and they they just

639.text:
refused to give me the support because it was a hassle.
So for me my tools weren't enough

647.text:
I had other things on the agenda so I
don't I don't feel like I'm at a

651.text:
complete loss. But I withdrew, I do
feel to this day I would have made a

656.text:
great teacher had I had the right tools
and awareness at that uni.

662.text: Then it would've been a completely different scenario.

665.text: So, the only way is up, as they say

668.text:
You might have noticed a logo on my beginning page 
Molly Watt Trust - back in 2011 my family and I

created this trust and it really
focuses on people like myself with

for Sense - you may or may not have heard

of, it's a massive charity for the deaf
blind. I do a bit of work for them.

690.text:
The only issue I found in the early days of
my diagnosis is because that charity is so

695.text:
massive and they cover such a massive
range of deafblindnesses, they're brilliant

699.text:
for older people who are deafblind,
younger children who are deafblind

703.text:
but people with Usher syndrome are 
ignored because we can see a bit,

708.text:
hear a bit and we appear to be capable,
so we don't get that support.

712.text: The Molly Watt Trust was created to try and push awareness about Usher Syndrome as well as

718.text:
fundraising for things that can help us on a daily basis.
So I altered my focus onto the

725.text:
charity, I thought this is a positive way
to take out my time after what was a bit

730.text:
down fall at uni. A lot of the came
back to access

all of the obstacles I've ever faced in my life have

what is that going to offer for someone like

Overwhelmed! I was so overwhelmed,
the main reason being when it was

So through vibrations and the maps

about on a daily basis. I mentioned

gate independence that really

As a trust we try and step in and help out

really found the benefit of using an

877.text:
On the charity we have a few

want to get a job, you want to succeed, but

904.text: you also need to accept who you are.

Which for someone who is going blind and

carpet and act okay and actually

I was in denial for a good 3 or 4 years and I tried

so you need the confidence, to be able to

929.text:
really get that technology to feel more

Really the Apple watch brings all

there is great for the blind, and great for the

For example one of the early things I found

you don't get anything from that,

and what was actually available

973.text:

979.text:

there is an app and is both on the

I didn't know what treble was

I was playing around with it, so again even at 21 I was

1012.text:
and things around me which is 
amazing!

1016.text:
So along with the app, I can also
stream music and it goes straight into

1019.text:
my ears, so I'm hearing music for the first

also the phone call thing, so it makes

1034.text:
more useful so when I'm out and
about my phones locked away in my bag

and stream straight into my ears.
And I can hear a phone call!

1054.text: These hearing aids have made a massive difference on the technology sides of things, also as a hearing

1062.text:
Before I had Phonak hearing aids and I thought they

however I would hear sound, but not
know where it's coming from. With the

1075.text:
ReSound hearing aids I have that
locational ability now, so if there's a

behind me, and for someone who is going

1083.text:
blind, that is massive! Really massive. 
So it's really helped.

1092.text:
Again going back to independence I can
get out and about safely with the Apple watch,

1097.text:
I can answer calls, I can feel the vibration for
directions on maps as well which is

1104.text:
amazing and in turn my confidence is
growing and a lot of people who are like

1109.text:
myself with the watch. We're hoping
to help more people get the ReSound

hearing aids also, 
but again, it's the

1117.text:
expense obstacle. Hopefully there''ll be more

1124.text:
Apple watches to really inspire their

1128.text:
Just on a side note from everything I've spoken about,
one main obstacle you probably

1134.text:
already figured out is ignorance.
A lot of people when they see me and I

1144.text:
"you don't look deafblind, you don't sound deaf, 
you don't look blind!"

1147.text:
Which if I had a pound for
every time someone said that to me I

1152.text:
would be rolling in it! It's sad but there's so
much ignorance out there, I have

1159.text: five degrees vision in one eye

1161.text:
my left eye has had it,
I'm completely blind in the dark

1165.text:
But this is how I am. I know a lot of people with 
Usher syndrome exactly the same

1171.text:
were born deaf and they were very visual so
they are still ironically quite visual.

1177.text:
I have written a
children's book and illustrated this book

1183.text:
so I'm quite creative and I do
still rely on that five degrees vision

1187.text:
that I still have, so there are ways around it. 
I use an iPad Pro

1192.text: for my art, I can zoom, and use lots of different apps

1197.text:
So using technology I'm able to do what I
can do.

1203.text:
One of the main things I found in my
lifetime is getting a job which was

1209.text:
barrier to trying to move forward with
this condition

1212.text:
a lot of employers as soon as you say
I'm registered deafblind

1216.text:
say "ok what are you gonna do for me"
or it's that immediate red cross and they don't even consider

1222.text:
you, which is a shame but happens a lot.
Something just to take away from

1229.text:
what I've just been talking about is
to recognize the capability of those

1235.text:
with a sensory impairment, whether it be
deaf, blind or deafblind

1238.text:
with the use of assistive accessible
technology is pretty massive.

1244.text:
A lot of sensory impairment there is no
cure, so technology is there to take part

1249.text:
in which I've lived to find
it does really help

1256.text:
hopefully it will improve even more as well.
As my mum often says:

1262.text:
"We have a unique skill set that's often waiting to
be unlocked" and it's quite true actually

1267.text:
I've done a lot of jobs and
using my experiences in using my

1273.text:

and how they could be more

accessible, I've consulted on accessibility, 
in various businesses

1282.text:
to really bring more inclusion into

I go into schools as well and talk awareness
and show my book and things like that as

1292.text:
well, to really push people to
realize that we are very capable, we can do

1298.text:
you know, not everything but we can do
more than you would expect so I'm quite

1304.text:
happy to take questions. One thing though

1308.text:

1316.text:
I met last night witnessed. It's not yet

It's a little mic

you can clip on or goes on a table and

around the table and it'll go straight

has proved to be amazing and so if

that is meant to work within 25 meters

there, someone might have to relay me questions

1389.text: or start thinking about accessibility needs

that would maybe last a year even from
concepting design and build, at what

1409.text: Right at beginning they should be considered. I think a lot of people with sensory impairment do tend

1417.text:
to turn to the web for research and
things like that. Kinda like the third

1421.text:
point of call when it comes to doing
any kind of research of any kind

1427.text:
think I accessibility should really
be considered in the early stages in

1432.text:
order to include everyone because I feel
it doesn't just cover people like

1437.text:
myself, it also covers the
aging society, people who are

1443.text:

your eyes start to fail,

We thoroughly endorse that view,

at the end. You design inclusively

QUESTION: Are there any other

You mentioned Apple and the iWatch is

1512.text:
It's not just been Apple, for example,
 if I'm reading a book I wouldn't

1523.text:
choose to use Apple, I'd choose a Kindle,
 just because of the paperback facility,

1529.text:
I don't like the glare. 
I can't use my Apple products for a

1533.text:
long period of time for that reason,
I get tired really quickly and

1538.text: it's not good for any of us.

1540.text: There's been other bits of gadgetry I've used as well,

1545.text:
they were provided for me
there was this box that I

1551.text:
scan across print or menus 
and it would enlarge,

but there was a lot of glare in it,

where you can change contrast etc.
would make a big

writing and things like that but I think

1569.text:
I always fall back on Apple products because I'm

to it. And it's the same with bits of

That's confusing when navigating all of the

I avoid doing that, I arrange it so

I have everything in my glances, so I just
swipe up, and alter my hearing aid

1689.text:
I can make a quick phone call 
It's just there for a convenience

1693.text:
thing. I think there are definitely a

get more out of it but I think
as a starting point it's a pretty good start.

From an independent point of view and
a safety point of view

1707.text:
just not having to have my
phone in my hand all the time makes a difference

the likelihood of someone stealing
this off my wrist as opposed to

1717.text: my iPhone 6S+ in my hand is

1719.text:
I think there's definitely
room for improvement I could probably if

1724.text:
I had the night to think about it I could
probably tell you a few things but

1728.text: off the top of my head I can't think of anything right now

1735.text: Any final questions before we wrap up?

1738.text: QUESTION: Do you think there is anything missing overall in the

1748.text:
technology world that you feel might
help you in your experience or

1754.text:
that you wish was
something that helped me with that

1758.text:
you feel is currently missing or for anybody
else?

1762.text: I think there's a lot of black

1764.text:
and white areas when it comes to accessibility, 
especially speaking from

1769.text:
someone who's got a dual sensory
impairment. A lot of people do kind of

1773.text:
think if you're blind you need
speaking stuff and if your deaf

1779.text:
you will need subtitles and you can't.
There's many gray areas in that

1787.text:
there's a very small percentage
of the blind population who are

1791.text:
completely blind and those who are deaf
don't necessarily need that much but

1797.text:
they need that consideration so I think
when it comes to trying to find things

1801.text:
that are accessible for someone with dual
impairment its you have to make

1806.text:
that choice between the blind
accessibility or the deaf accessibility

1810.text:
so there's a big group of people in the
middle who could really benefit from

1815.text:
something a joint thing, that's
why our collaboration with the

1822.text:
ReSound hearing aids and Apple watch
together they bring the two together

1825.text:
that's the closest I've had to deafblind
accessible technology, everything else is

1831.text:
deaf or blind and there's nothing in the
middle, that's something that we

1837.text:
really need to work on.
I couldn't tell you now what would solve

1841.text:
that, but it's definitely something that
needs to be worked on.

1856.text:
QUESTION: When I think
of accessibility and accessibility options,

1862.text:
I think of increasing font sizes
and I think of increasing contrast,

1869.text:
are there any subtler elements of user
interface design and technology

1873.text:
design in general which greatly benefits
people with limited visibility limited hearing?

1880.text: As in like on a web site?

1883.text:
Yeah, so you're right in terms of the
contrast and color change on the font

1890.text:
also I think it's when you're
looking at videos and picture changing

1896.text:
movements. A lot of things that
I've been on have got writing over

1901.text:
moving pictures in the background -
it's not wise!

1906.text:
For someone trying to follow the text
and there's something going on in
the background I think kind of having

1911.text:
that subtle changes being able to pause
the picture and change contrast

1915.text:
and move the text, would make a difference.
I went and saw

1921.text:
Just Giving in their offices and I was
looking at their website and critiquing

1927.text:
one of the things they had was when you 
scroll down, the picture moved and the text stayed

1933.text:
I could not see the logic
like "this is confusing!"

1938.text:
I think subtle differences and make
a massive difference to those who are

1944.text:
like myself when it comes to looking
online or keynote presentation. The whole

1948.text:
setup of my keynote - dark
background with lighter text,

1953.text: it's a lot easier on the eye.

1957.text:
For less glare and things like
that if not the

1962.text:
yellowy off-white background with black
writing are also okay.

1967.text:
On my website we made it very clear where you
can go to accessibility and alter the

1974.text:
different settings and things like that
so the first thing you see when you go onto website -

1978.text:
Accessibility > Font Change > Contrast
and have columns

1985.text:
when you have lots of
clutter you don't know where to look

1989.text:
and you're scanning around- that's also hellish.
For example Facebook, when you go on the computer

1997.text:
there's so many things going on so many
different columns -  it's not enjoyable

2001.text:
whereas Twitter is great, you have just
one column to scroll and have the

2007.text:
contrast and the text in the right
format and you're good to go.

2011.text:
A lot of it is keeping it fairly simplistic
and having the option to alter it just

2018.text:
just as you mentioned before contrast,
colors, font and also just the pictures I think

2024.text:
that's always a good thing to consider
as well

2031.text: Okay one more question if you will.

2046.text:
QUESTION: Molly, what's your favourite website? That works for you.
>> Can I say mine? [Laughs]

2055.text: And which is the website that you'd like to work for you, to become your new favourite?

2061.text: So which is your most favourite because it works for you?

2065.text:
It's well-designed and which is the website
that you would really like to be your

2069.text:
favorite but has actually got lots of
accessibility problems?

2076.text:
my website, and my trust both sites.
I have two websites, my personal blogging

2082.text:
website and I have my charity
website they're both setup very similarly so

2089.text:
ideally it'd be great to have all of them like that.
Which you'll understand when you go on there

2095.text:
it clearly states accessibility, and all the
various features you can have on there

2105.text:
it's gotta comeback to the
social networking websites, because a lot

2111.text:
of people who live in isolation, a lot of
people in my shoes, for example, people

2115.text:
who don't feel confident enough to go
out and do anything, they turn to social

2119.text:
media to really reach out and find other
people like themselves. However things like

2125.text:
Facebook is really inaccessible and is a
real challenge I mean I only ever use it

2131.text:
really on an iPad and how to really zoom,
and I very rarely use it I much rather

2136.text:
use Twitter as I explained before.
It's massive, as we all know but a

2144.text:
lot of people go on Facebook and try
and find other people like themselves and

2148.text:
actually that's an obstacle because they can't
access it. The font can't change

2152.text:
or anything like that. Of course if you can
afford a Macbook, a PC that has the zoom feature

2158.text:
and you can alter it that's great,
but if you can't afford that and you've

2164.text:
just got old this computer you just want to
reach out to someone, there's that barrier

2170.text:
straightaway of not being able to
access it.

2175.text:
Okay, thank you Molly once again

snoozed the whole time on the stage here.
